The Ismaili Muslim community in the Pamir Mountains has developed a unique set of religious practices that are distinct from other sects of Islam. The Pamiri Ismailis refer to their faith as "Tariqah-i muminan" or "The Path of the Faithful." The religious practices and rituals of the Ismaili Muslims in the region are unique to their community, reflecting the diverse cultural traditions of the region.

The Aga Khan is regarded as the spiritual leader of the Ismaili Muslims worldwide, and his guidance is highly respected by the community in the Pamir Mountains. The Ismaili community in the region follows a set of spiritual and moral principles, including the belief in the oneness of God, the importance of community service, and mutuality, which is a reciprocal sense of responsibility and cooperation among the community members.

The Ismailis in the region are also known for their reverence of nature, which is reflected in their religious beliefs and practices. For example, the Aga Khan Foundation has invested in the revival of the traditional Pamiri practice of pasture management, which aims to preserve the natural environment and protect the livelihoods of pastoralists in the region.

The Ismaili Muslims in the Pamir Mountains also celebrate various festivals and events, such as Navroz (New Year) and the Diamond Jubilee of the Aga Khan, which was celebrated in 2017. The celebrations often involve music, dance, and the sharing of traditional food and drink.

Overall, the Ismaili Muslim community in the Pamir Mountains follows a unique set of religious practices and rituals that reflect their diverse cultural traditions and reverence for nature. The guidance and leadership of the Aga Khan and the support of the Aga Khan Foundation have been instrumental in enabling the community to preserve their religious and cultural heritage.
